head.title: Terrorism Must Not Drive Us Behind a Wall;State Terrorism

hedline.hl1: Terrorism Must Not Drive Us Behind a Wall;State Terrorism

block.p: Ronald Steel (Op-Ed, July 21) misses an important point. Not all terrorists "operate outside of the contrived world of state-sanctioned violence." Many terrorists operate with the covert and sometimes overt help of certain states.

Ronald Steel (Op-Ed, July 21) misses an important point. Not all terrorists "operate outside of the contrived world of state-sanctioned violence." Many terrorists operate with the covert and sometimes overt help of certain states.

The best example of this is the two Libyans indicted for the bombing of Pan Am 103, in which 270 people, including my daughter, were killed over Lockerbie, Scotland, in 1988. The indictment described the two as Libyan "agents." They are alive and free in Libya.

It is long past time that the United States began to treat the war against terrorism as a real war. Mr. Steel says that states don't do certain terrible things because they fear retaliation. Terrorist states like Libya should be made to feel that fear.
DANIEL COHEN Cape May Court House, N.J. July 21, 1996
